department: Art of Africa and the Americas
description: headdress with leather cap/headpiece with beaded band around front top with white beads with two lines of blue triangles, two red bars and two lines of red and orange triangles at either end; long red wool strips at each side of headdress, backed with buffalo hide; brown and cream eagle feathers overall; some feathers at top have light brown horsehair strands attached to ends; eagle feather at center back accented with bright red and bright purple feathers; images of cows' heads drawn on leather beneath feathers on crown of head
markings: at bottom feather on one side, on tag: [6019 / OTTT] and [Sioux Chief\'s / Bonnett / probably made / around 1900]; on interior at same area, on tag: [Joe / Bartles (?--partially illegible)] and [No. / 1261 / C.C.C.]
medium: Bald eagle and other feathers, wool, buffalo hide, cowhide, horsehair, beads, pigments
text: This headdress was donated to the museum by Jack Garcia, a Lakota man who is a descendant of Long Wolf, a great warrior and leader who fought at the Battle of Little Bighorn. An iconic symbol of Native art, Plains eagle feather headdresses exude beauty, boldness, grace, and strength. Made by a Cheyenne or Lakota artist, this headdress contains more than twenty eagle feathers, indicating the wearer of this piece was an esteemed member of the Native community. Each eagle feather represents individual accomplishments, extraordinary generosity, and great leadership.
title: Headdress
